text: bye sweet corn is an important vegetable crop in the northeast freshly picked locally grown sweet corn is popular among consumers who like to be able to buy it at roadside stands farmers markets and supermarkets to grow a marketable crop of sweet corn farmers must provide adequate soil fertility control insect pests and manage weeds in this video farmers describe production practices that they use to grow a good crop of corn without excessive use of fertilizers insecticides or herbicides these ecological production practices can help enhance profits while protecting natural resources farmers can decide for themselves which of these practices makes sense for their operation i'm alex mclennan and i farm in the connecticut river valley in windsor vermont on sandy silt loam soils i grow about 50 acres of vegetables that's about 20 acres in sweet corn 20 acres in pumpkins and about 10 acres of green beans i started using hairy vetch oh i'd say about four or five years ago now basically i was looking for something i don't have animals i don't have manure so i've been trying to find cover crops that that fit in well with a fairly intensive vegetable production so that we don't wear out the soil i like the veg for a source of nitrogen because i'm looking for something with a bit of a time release to it as opposed to just throwing on urea and having it having it go into solution too quickly i also use the vetch specifically because i don't take land out of production for an entire growing season so i'm trying to have a cover crop on the land basically all the time that there's not a there's not a cash crop on there i seed vetch from 15 to 30 pounds to the acre the 30 pound rate gives a real nice stand but some years of etch seed is very expensive and sometimes i just economize by cutting back to a rate as low as 15 pounds i still get a reasonably good stand with 15 pounds to the acre that is seeded at the same time as the oats which is usually at about a bushel to the acre and that seems to work out well for giving me a fall cover we inoculate the vetch seed to make sure that we get good nodulation because the whole purpose really of the of the hairy vetch cover crop is to get nitrogen fixation we turn the vetch under in preparation for for planting usually around the second to third week of may i like to i like to hold off as long as i possibly can and get as much nitrogen out of the veg as i can before i plow it under hairy vetch has never been a problem in in in volunteer production or or weed production we never had any problem turning it under and killing it very easily without any chemical use so the vetch gives me additional biomass a little bit better soil structure additional nitrogen and erosion protection for the winter and early spring the major drawback to using vetch has been the cost of the seed but as long as it stays under two dollars a pound i intend to continue to use it and i think it's done a great job in my soils

sweet corn is an important vegetable
crop in the northeast
freshly picked locally grown sweet corn
is popular among consumers
who like to be able to buy it at
roadside stands farmers markets
and supermarkets to grow a marketable
crop of sweet corn
farmers must provide adequate soil
fertility
control insect pests and manage weeds
in this video farmers describe
production practices that they use to
grow a good crop of corn without
excessive use of fertilizers
insecticides or herbicides
these ecological production practices
can help enhance profits
while protecting natural resources
farmers can decide for themselves which
of these practices makes sense
for their operation

connecticut river valley in windsor
vermont
on sandy silt loam soils i grow about
50 acres of vegetables

20 acres in pumpkins and about 10 acres
of green beans

about four or five years ago now
basically i was looking for something i

crops that that fit in well with a
fairly intensive vegetable production so
that we don't wear out the soil
i like the veg for a source of nitrogen
because i'm looking for something with a
bit of a time release to it
as opposed to just throwing on urea and
having it having it
go into solution too quickly
i also use the vetch specifically
because i don't take land out of

and that seems to work out well for

to make sure that we get good nodulation

and get as much nitrogen out of the veg

plow it under hairy vetch has never been

in in volunteer production or

problem turning it under and killing it

without any chemical use so the vetch
gives me additional biomass a little bit
better soil structure
additional nitrogen and erosion

for the winter and early spring the
major drawback to using vetch has been

but as long as it stays under two
